<html><head><title>HTML - The Basics Tutorial - Part 1</title>
<!--Description and keywords generated by script--><meta name="description" content="Learn how to create a site by coding your own HTML or how to change pre-made HTML to fit into your site. (Free Webmaster Help)">
<meta name="keywords" content="html, hyper, text, markup, mark, up, language, make, webpage, page, web, design, create, produce, how, tutorial, teach, learn, source, code, beginner">
<!-- Standard Heading -->
<meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">
<script language="JavaScript">
<!--
function MM_swapImgRestore() { //v3.0
  var i,x,a=document.MM_sr; for(i=0;a&&i<a.length&&(x=a[i])&&x.oSrc;i++) x.src=x.oSrc;
}

function MM_preloadImages() { //v3.0
  var d=document; if(d.images){ if(!d.MM_p) d.MM_p=new Array();
    var i,j=d.MM_p.length,a=MM_preloadImages.arguments; for(i=0; i<a.length; i++)
    if (a[i].indexOf("#")!=0){ d.MM_p[j]=new Image; d.MM_p[j++].src=a[i];}}
}

function MM_findObj(n, d) { //v4.0
  var p,i,x;  if(!d) d=document; if((p=n.indexOf("?"))>0&&parent.frames.length) {
    d=parent.frames[n.substring(p+1)].document; n=n.substring(0,p);}
  if(!(x=d[n])&&d.all) x=d.all[n]; for (i=0;!x&&i<d.forms.length;i++) x=d.forms[i][n];
  for(i=0;!x&&d.layers&&i<d.layers.length;i++) x=MM_findObj(n,d.layers[i].document);
  if(!x && document.getElementById) x=document.getElementById(n); return x;
}

function MM_swapImage() { //v3.0
  var i,j=0,x,a=MM_swapImage.arguments; document.MM_sr=new Array; for(i=0;i<(a.length-2);i+=3)
   if ((x=MM_findObj(a[i]))!=null){document.MM_sr[j++]=x; if(!x.oSrc) x.oSrc=x.src; x.src=a[i+2];}
}
//-->
</script>

            			<!-- Page Title -->
                       <p align="center"><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="5"><b><font color="#000099" size="6">
                       HTML - The Basics Tutorial<br>
              <font size="4" color="#000000">Part 1 - Your First Page</font></font></b></font></p>

              <!-- Links To Other Tutorial Parts -->
              <font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><ul><li><b>Part 1 - Your First Page</b></li><li><a href="http://www.freewebmasterhelp.com/tutorials/html-basics/2">Part 2 - Adding Text</a></li><li><a href="http://www.freewebmasterhelp.com/tutorials/html-basics/3">Part 3 - Positioning Text</a></li><li><a href="http://www.freewebmasterhelp.com/tutorials/html-basics/4">Part 4 - Hyperlinks and Bookmarks</a></li><li><a href="http://www.freewebmasterhelp.com/tutorials/html-basics/5">Part 5 - Images & Backgrounds</a></li></ul></font>

              <!-- Page Content -->
              <p><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">
              <div align="right" style="float:right">
<iframe src="http://rcm.amazon.com/e/cm?t=freewebmaster-20&o=1&p=14&l=st1&mode=books&search=html&fc1=000000&lt1=&lc1=3366FF&bg1=FFFFFF&f=ifr" marginwidth="0" marginheight="0" width="160" height="600" border="0" frameborder="0" style="border:none;" scrolling="no"></iframe>
</div><font face="Arial" color="#000099"><big><b>Introduction</b></big></font><br />
<br />
HTML is the language that makes the web work. It is the usual programming language used for most web sites you will visit. It is understood by nearly every computer in the world and is one of the most universal ways of creating documents. HTML may not have the best formatting tools and you cannot guarantee that your pages will look the same in every single browser but without it there would be no internet.<br />
<br />
You can, of course, use a WYSIWYG (What You See Is What You Get) HTML editor to make websites but they have 3 main disadvantages:<br />
<ol><br />
<li>They sometimes use excess code to create a look on a page which slows down loading times </li><br />
<li>They do not always create fully compatible code </li><br />
<li>Some WYSIWYG editors change any HTML code you enter by hand </li></ol><br />
Because of these you can create much better pages by writing HTML by hand. I must admit that I don&#039;t do this much because it is much slower than using a WYSIWYG editor but I still know HTML as it is always good to have a background knowledge. I assure you that if you learn HTML you will create better web pages.<br />
<br />
This tutorial will show you the basics of writing HTML.<br />
<br />
<font face="Arial" color="#000099"><big><b>What Software?</b></big></font><br />
<br />
You do not actually need any specialist software to write HTML code and many web designers argue that the best web sites are created in Notepad! For this tutorial, though, I will be using one of my favorite web design programs, FirstPage 2000. It is free and you can download it here.<br />
<br />
Some of the advantages of using an HTML editor is that it will color code your HTML code so that it is easier to read, &#039;clean up&#039; your code when you have finished, and you can use buttons in the software to insert repetitive code.<br />
<br />
It doesn&#039;t matter if you are using Notepad, FirstPage 2000 or another HTML editor, this tutorial will actually be teaching you the language.<br />
<br />
<font face="Arial" color="#000099"><big><b>Understanding HTML</b></big></font><br />
<br />
The actual HTML language is very easy to learn once you know the basics. HTML is made up of a tag. A tag is a piece of text contained in &lt;&gt; and looks something like this:<br />
<font face="Arial" color="#0000FF"><br />
&lt;tag&gt;<br />
</font><br />
There are two types of tag. Opening and closing tags. Closing tags are only different as they have a / before them:<br />
<font face="Arial" color="#0000FF"><br />
&lt;/tag&gt;<br />
</font><br />
Tags appear in pairs like this:<br />
<font face="Arial" color="#0000FF"><br />
&lt;tag&gt;&lt;/tag&gt;<br />
</font><br />
You are probably not really understanding this so I will explain further. Anything between two tags will have those tags applied to them. A good example of this is using the &lt;center&gt; tag to center align text:<br />
<font face="Arial" color="#0000FF"><br />
&lt;center&gt;Text in here is centered&lt;/center&gt;<br />
</font><br />
Nearly all tags have a closing tag but a few do not. What you must remember is:<br />
<b><br />
&lt;Tag&gt;Text&lt;/Tag&gt;<br />
</b><br />
<font face="Arial" color="#000099"><big><b>Declaring HTML</b></big></font><br />
<br />
Open the program you are using to write HTML. If you are using an HTML editor you will have some code already entered. If you do not have it already, enter the following:<br />
<font face="Arial" color="#0000FF"><br />
&lt;!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC &quot;-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0 Transitional//EN&quot;&gt;<br />
<br />
&lt;html&gt;<br />
&lt;head&gt;<br />
&lt;title&gt;Untitled&lt;/title&gt;<br />
&lt;/head&gt;<br />
<br />
&lt;body&gt;<br />
<br />
&lt;/body&gt;<br />
&lt;/html&gt;<br />
</font><br />
I will explain what all this means below:<br />
<font face="Arial" color="#0000FF"><br />
&lt;!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC &quot;-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0 Transitional//EN&quot;&gt;<br />
</font><br />
This tells the browser what language is being used for the page. It is not entirely necessary but it is good to add it in.<br />
<font face="Arial" color="#0000FF"><br />
&lt;html&gt;<br />
</font><br />
Tells the browser that this is the beginning of an HTML document.<br />
<font face="Arial" color="#0000FF"><br />
&lt;head&gt;<br />
</font><br />
This is the beginning of the header section. The header section contains the configuration options for the page (like title).<br />
<font face="Arial" color="#0000FF"><br />
&lt;title&gt;Untitled&lt;/title&gt;<br />
</font><br />
This tells the browser what to display as the title of the page. This appears in the title bar at the top of the browser. Enter the name of your page between the &lt;title&gt; tags.<br />
<font face="Arial" color="#0000FF"><br />
&lt;/head&gt;<br />
</font><br />
<br />
End of the header section.<br />
<font face="Arial" color="#0000FF"><br />
&lt;body&gt;<br />
<br />
&lt;/body&gt;<br />
</font><br />
Everything between these is in the body of the page. This is where all text, images etc. are. This is the most important part of the page.<br />
<font face="Arial" color="#0000FF"><br />
&lt;/html&gt;<br />
</font><br />
Shows the end of the HTML document.<br />
<br />
<font face="Arial" color="#000099"><big><b>Summary</b></big></font><br />
<br />
This concludes this week&#039;s tutorial. You have learned how HTML is structured using &lt;tag&gt;text&lt;/tag&gt;. You must always remember that whatever is between a starting tag &lt;tag&gt; and an ending tag &lt;/tag&gt; will have the tag applied to it. You have also learned how to set the page&#039;s title and declare an HTML document<br />
<br />
<font face="Arial" color="#000099"><big><b>Part 2</b></big></font><br />
<br />
In part 2 will show you how to add text to your page and format it.</font></p>

              <!-- Bottom Navigation -->
              <table width="100%" cellspacing="2" cellpadding="2" border="0">
              <tr>
              
              
              
              <!-- Links To Other Tutorial Parts -->
              <td width="50%" valign="top"><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><ul><li><b>Part 1 - Your First Page</b></li><li><a href="http://www.freewebmasterhelp.com/tutorials/html-basics/2">Part 2 - Adding Text</a></li><li><a href="http://www.freewebmasterhelp.com/tutorials/html-basics/3">Part 3 - Positioning Text</a></li><li><a href="http://www.freewebmasterhelp.com/tutorials/html-basics/4">Part 4 - Hyperlinks and Bookmarks</a></li><li><a href="http://www.freewebmasterhelp.com/tutorials/html-basics/5">Part 5 - Images & Backgrounds</a></li></ul></font></p></td>
              
              <!-- Related Links -->
              <td width="50%" valign="top">
              <font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><ul>
                   <li><a href="http://www.meteorsurf.com/cgi-bin/smartsearch/smartsearch.cgi?username=gowansnet&keywords=html">More HTML - The Basics Sites</a></li><li><a href="#amazonlinks">Related Reading</a></li>
</ul></font>
</td>

			 <!-- End Bottom Navigation -->
			 </tr></table>

        	<!-- Gowansnet Link -->
            
            
             </td><td width="9">&nbsp;</td>
        </tr>
      </table>
    </td>
  </tr>
</table>
</td>
</tr>
